course_description: Common sentence forms and vocabulary taught by audio-lingual methods. Listening to, reading and writing stories recorded by native speakers are used. Materials are chosen for cultural and linguistic content. Extended dialogues and storytelling to increase fluency in speech and reading. Transcription of and response to recorded language samples to extend writing in the Cayuga language.
prerequisites: Notes: This course will run on-line synchronous in the Fa ll term. The Winter term will run in-person, room TBS. this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Indigenous cultures in contemporary North America. Diverse and common features of different nations; effects of geography, politics, history and language use.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: The traditional Indigenous family from pre-contact to the contemporary. Topics include commonalities among cultures, dynamics of family change and development, traditional family planning and parenting as well as individual, family and community relationships and roles.
prerequisites: Notes: This course will run on-line synchronous in the Fa ll term. The Winter term will run in-person, room TBS. this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: Intro to Indigenous Education in Canada
course_description: Overview of First Nation, Metis and Inuit education in Canada. Examination of various Indigenous traditions, philosophies and culturally-based models from both historical and contemporary Indigenous perspectives. Indigenous perspectives on the current state and future direction of teaching and research.
prerequisites: Notes: This course will run on-line synchronous in the Fa ll term. The Winter term will run in-person, room TBS. this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Introduction of the culture of a selected Indigenous Society to early childhood educators.
prerequisites: Exclusions: Students will not receive earned credit in INDG 2F95 if ABST 2F96 has been successfully completed.

course_description: Culture of a selected Indigenous society emphasizing the cultural perceptions, developments and interpretations of that society.

course_description: Comparative survey of Indigenous spiritual traditions and the influence on contemporary lifestyle and thought of peoples residing in Canada and the United States.

course_description: Impact of colonialism on Indigenous peoples from Confederation to present day. Social, economic, and cultural impact on various First Nation, Metis and Inuit peoples of Canada.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Theatrical, dramatic and performative representation of Indigenous peoples in the Canadian experience.
prerequisites: Exclusions: Completion of this course will replace previous assigned grade and credit obtained in ABST 2P96.

course_description: Stories embedded within the literature as they apply to contemporary settings. Exploration of the power of Indigenous women's writing as a political and educational tool.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as WGST 3P47

course_description: Indigenous ideologies of mothering and motherhood from a variety of perspectives. Historical mothering practices and family structures highlighting unique roles of Indigenous women in many communities. Contemporary understandings of Indigenous ideologies of motherhood.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as SOCI 3P81 and WGST 3P81

course_description: Historic and contemporary portrayals of women, land, spirituality, politics, education and Indigenous people in the media from an Indigenous perspective.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as SOCI 3P81 and WGST 3P81

course_description: Draws on cultural, experiential and theoretical texts to better understand Indigenous epistemologies. Examples include ImagineNative and community arts projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): one of, one INDG (ABST) credit, COMM 1F90, PCUL 1F92, SOCI 1F90, WGST 1F90, 2P00 or permission of the instructor.

course_description: Re-conceptualizes feminisms within a transnational Indigenous framework. Topics include debates within Indigenous knowledge production, analyses of genders and sexualities, violence, poverty, the politics of reproduction, cultural identities, media, and environmental and social justice.
prerequisites: Exclusions: Completion of this course will replace previous assigned grade and credit obtained in INDG (SOCI/WGST) 2P97.

course_description: History and contemporary literatures on Indigenous epistemologies, the political philosophy of movements for decolonization, environmental sustainability, and Indigenous writing on gendered justice and cultural resurgence in a globalizing world emphasizing writings by Indigenous scholars.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): one of, one INDG (ABST) credit, two SOCI credits, two WGST credits or permission of the Department of Sociology Administrator.
